description: From Middle English attercoppe, from Old English ātorcoppe (“spider”), corresponding to atter (“poison, venom”) +‎ cop (“spider”). The latter is still to be found in the English word cobweb. Cognate to Dutch etterkop (“peevish or ill-natured person”) and Danish edderkop (“spider”).

examples: Myself, not bound by James’ viewNor Walter’s, in a vision saw these twoLike trapped and weakening fliesIn toils of the same hoary net;I seemed to hear ancestral criesBuzzing ‘To our All-Wise, OmnivorousAttercop glowering over us,Whose table we have setWith blood and bones and sweat.’

entries.meaning: (dialectal, Northern England) A peevish or ill-natured person.
